On Tue, 11 Nov 2003, James Cheesman wrote:

> Doesn't JUnit do this already? At least if I run the tests with ant I
> get an output similar to:
>
> Testcase: testDateIsActiveNullDate took 0,016 sec
> Testcase: testDateIsActiveToday took 0,031 sec
> Testcase: testDateIsActivePast took 0,047 sec
> ...
>
> I'm not sure how much use this kind of micro-testing would be, though
> I'm sure you could set up your test cases to provide more valid data.

I haven't done very careful testing, but I certainly have noticed that
the times reported by JUnit vary a great deal.

Running one simple set of tests just now gave me results in which 50%
differences were common and more than one test took 3x as long from one
run to the next.  So, sure, you can use JUnit for this sort of simple
performance testing, but you should at least run the tests enough times to
build statistical confidence in the results.

It didn't show up in these few runs, but I believe that I have noticed
before that the first test reported a much longer than normal time --
seconds rather than milliseconds.  So the order in which tests are run
might introduce an effect large enough to render the results useless.
